subject: US President Trump announces conditional decision for a peace deal with the Taliban
analysis_details: • There were previous reports that US is prepared to sign a deal with the Taliban that would see the withdrawal of US troops and the start of peace talks between the insurgents and the Afghan government, although a deal would only proceed if the Taliban adhere to a pledge to reduce violence over a 7-day period.

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

WHO said the number of newly confirmed coronavirus cases has declined steadily for the past week but added that it must be interpreted with extreme caution and that the outbreak could still go in any direction. (Newswires)

CDC said it is seeing "fewer and fewer" travellers from China and no new cases at US airports, while it added new controls to avoid testing mishaps with the coronavirus and is likely to see some "community spread" in the US. (Newswires)

China's Communist Party Standing Committee is to implement prudent monetary policy including differentiated virus-curbing measures, while it is to enhance the strength of macro-policy adjustments, according to State TV. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin does not expect the coronavirus to have an impact on economic growth beyond this year, while he talked with Fed Chair Powell on the global economic impact of coronavirus and agreed it's too soon to say what the impact will be. Furthermore, Mnuchin added that the implementation of the mini-trade deal with China has slowed down due to the nCoV and that the entire "chapters" of Phase Two have been "dealt with". (Newswires)

RBNZ Governor Orr stated the coronavirus will only have an impact on monetary policy if the outbreak lasts for a sustained period, while he is confident monetary policy is working and is encouraged by fiscal support from the government. (Newswires)

  • Indian CPI Inflation (Jan) Y/Y 7.59% vs. Exp. 7.4% (Prev. 7.35%). (Newswires)
  • Indian Industrial Output (Dec) Y/Y -0.3% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)
  • Indian Manufacturing Output (Dec) Y/Y -1.2% (Prev. 2.7%)

 

EU

  • EU Industrial Production (Dec) M/M -2.1% vs. Exp. -1.6% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires)
  • EU Industrial Production (Dec) Y/Y -4.1% vs. Exp. -2.3% (Prev. -1.5%, Rev. -1.7%)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 7.459M vs. Exp. 2.987M (Prev. 3.355M). (Newswires)

Russian Energy Ministry official confirmed no decision yet on OPEC+ deal. Furthermore, Russia’s Lukoil noted most Russian companies want the cuts to be continued for one more quarter, while RussNeft said it wants oil deal to remain in place and consolidated decision to be taken later. (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report (Feb): 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 230k BPD from prior report to 990k BPD in which the coronavirus outbreak is the major factor behind the downward revision. Preliminary data indicated that global oil supply in January decreased by 10k BPD M/M to an average of 100.12mln BPD, up 780k BPD Y/Y, while OPEC crude production fell by 509k BPD M/M to average 28.86mln BPD according to secondary sources. Furthermore, crude output increased in Saudi Arabia and Nigeria although production decreased mainly in Libya (-344k BPD MM), Iraq and Kuwait. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said the senate should not vote for the Iran war powers resolution and suggested that the US is doing very well with Iran and this is not the time to show weakness, while he added that Iran would have a field day if his hands were tied which sends a very bad signal. (Newswires)

Russian Defence Ministry said Turkey has failed to separate moderate opposition militants from terrorists in the Idlib area, while it added that they are convinced Russia and Turkey can successfully complete their Syrian mission by avoiding hasty decisions. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said he thinks the idea of putting treasury and reserves on an equal footing is a “good goal” and that he would now be concerned about the level of US debt. Furthermore, he added we will be able to see the impact of the coronavirus outbreak in the economic data "fairly soon". (Newswires)

Fed’s Daly (Non-Voter, Neutral) said average inflation targeting over a long period makes sense and is not talking about much above 2%, while she added the natural rate of unemployment is currently lower than we had thought. (Newswires)

  • US Federal Budget (USD)(Jan) -33.0B vs. Exp. -11.5B (Prev. -13.3B). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Risk appetite grew further on Wednesday, seeing all three major US equity indices set fresh ATHs - defensive sectors underperformed - alongside a strong bid in the crude complex, despite a bearish EIA inventory report and OPEC cutting demand forecasts. The session got off on the front foot following a declining reported rate of new coronavirus cases and deaths, adding support to the "transitory" nature of the outbreak, raising hopes of a v-shaped global recovery. Micron (MU) traded with solid gains following an upgrade at UBS, where the desk noted the time has finally arrived when MU can materially outperform over a sustained period, believing it is in a much stronger position in a better-positioned industry on the cusp of a cyclical upswing, and that DRAM should perform well in 2021. Elsewhere in the Semiconductor space, Qualcomm (QCOM) opened higher following an upgrade at Daiwa, who noted the potential QCOM has due to its 5G positioning. The energy sector drove gains in the SPX as oil prices rebounded today following the recent heavy declines. SPX +0.64% at 3379, DJIA +0.9% at 29,551, NDX +1% at 9613.

The TPLEX bear steepened on Wednesday, ahead of Treasury supply with the T-Note seeing the most pronounced selling (compared to other maturities), as risk appetite continued to improve. Similar to Tuesday, the majority of the move happened in the overnight session, before finding its floor in early European trade. Desks note the selling was lead by real money as dealers sought concession ahead of the 10-year auction, in what was, more broadly, the most expensive since October. Nonetheless, the USD 27bln refunding auction was fairly decent, stopping through the 1.623% WI by 0.1bps, covered 2.58x (vs. six-auction average 2.41x), and dealers didn’t have to take down as much as usual, with both directs and indirects taking more than average. How much higher the 10-year yield can move in the near term remains up to debate, there are suggestions of algos/programme sellers “lurking” above 1.64% on the 10-year yield, a level which heavy gamma hedging took place last week, a level which could be tested if expectations move closer to that of a v-shaped recovery in the global economy post the coronavirus. By settlement, yields were higher across the curve with the 10-year yield at 1.63%, seeing the 2s10s widen by just under 1.5bps. US T-note futures (H20) settled 10 ticks lower at 130-22.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 12th February 2020: Declining rate of nCoV cases keeps rally going
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Slowing reported nCoV cases and deaths in China; Sanders narrowly wins NH Primary; OPEC cuts 2020 world oil demand growth forecast, citing nCoV; RBNZ and Riksbank stand pat.
  • COMING UP: Events/Data: US CPI, Jobless Claims, IEA Monthly Oil Report; German CPI; Mexican Rate Decision. Speakers: Fed’s Williams; ECB’s Lane, Panetta, de Cos; BoC’s Poloz; RBA’s Lowe. Auctions: NY Fed Repo Schedule; US 30-year Bond and TIPs. Earnings: NVDA, PEP, LIN, FIS, DUK, ZTE, WM, AIG, KHC, DLR; AIR FP, TKA GY, CBK GY, RI FP, VIV FP

* MARKETS WRAP: Risk appetite grew further on Wednesday, seeing all three major US equity indices set fresh ATHs - defensive sectors underperformed - alongside a strong bid in the crude complex, despite a bearish EIA inventory report and OPEC cutting demand forecasts. The session got off on the front foot following a declining reported rate of new coronavirus cases and deaths, adding support to the "transitory" nature of the outbreak, raising hopes of a v-shaped global recovery. Meanwhile, the DXY topped the key 99.00 figure, whilst the Euro cross dipped beneath the 1.09 figure to multi-year lows - XAU traded slightly lower. Further supporting the greenback was the bear steepening of the Treasury curve, with the T-Note seeing the most pronounced selling ahead of its auction/refunding, which fared decent demand.  Looking ahead, earnings from NVDA and PEP are expected on Thursday, as is the Fed's less preferred inflation measure, CPI (Jan), whilst participants will also be looking for more signs of the coronavirus outbreak abating.

* CORONAVIRUS: China reported an additional 2015 coronavirus cases and 97 deaths as of February 11th vs. 2478 additional cases and 108 deaths on Feb. 10th, to bring total confirmed cases to 44653 and death toll at 1113. Goldman Sachs’ analysts, using their “high-frequency indicators for tracking the spread” of the virus, also note a declining rate of new cases in both Hubei and the rest of mainland China, suggesting to the bank that the slowing is probably due to the strict travel control and self-isolation. Participants are constrained on whether the virus will prove to be transitory, such as previous similar outbreaks (SARS/MERS) have been, or could hold a more systemic change to the global supply chain and global output.

* FED POWELL TESTIMONY: Fed Chair Powell, in the final day of his Senate Testimony, said we will be able to see the impact of the coronavirus outbreak in the economic data "fairly soon," after yesterday announcing they were studying it closely. Powell added that he thinks the idea of putting Treasuries and reserves on an equal footing is a “good goal” – following the repo market’s squeeze last year which saw PDs struggle to attain cash for their Treasury holdings. Powell said that he is now concerned about the level of US debt. Elsewhere on the economy, the Fed Chair stated there is nothing about that is unbalanced or out of kilter, noting that there is a squeeze going on in the US housing sector due to a lack of affordability and that he believes there is more upside to the labour participation rate; note, yesterday Powell said the Fed would “never” say it had accomplished the goal of making sure anyone who wants to work and can work will have a job available for them.

* NEW HAMPSHIRE DEMOCRAT PRIMARY: After Tuesday evening’s Primary, Sanders came out in front, as expected, at 25.7%, although Buttigieg came narrowly second at 24.4%, a narrower margin than Sanders would probably have liked to see given his supposed dominance in the State. Furthermore, Klobuchar came third at 19.8%, making solid ground following polls (Warren fourth at 9.2% and Biden fifth at 8.4%) that put the Minnesota Senator in the single digits. One UBS analyst notes Klobuchar’s mid-Western and Middle America appeal could have her stand a good fight against President Trump, noting her grossing popularity on the back of the Iowa caucus, although caveats that her “impassioned centrism” could serve as her weak point.

* FED: Fed’s Daly (non-voter, dovish) said average inflation targeting over a long period makes sense, but not talking about much above 2%. Daly added that right now the natural rate of unemployment is lower than we thought heading into the expansion, but believes it is where we currently are at around 3.5%.

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC cut its 2020 global oil demand growth forecast by 230k BPD from its prior report to 990k BPD – the outbreak of the Coronavirus in China during H1 is the major factor behind the downward revision. The report added that preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in January decreased by 10k BPD to an average of 100.12mln BPD, up by 780k BPD Y/Y. In January, OPEC crude production fell by 509k BPD M/M to average 28.86mln BPD, according to secondary sources. Crude output increased in Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, while production decreased mainly in Libya (-344k BPD MM), Iraq, and Kuwait. Click here for the full release.

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 1.23 HIGHER AT USD 51.17/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 1.78 HIGHER AT USD 55.79/BBL. Energy outperformed on Wednesday alongside equities, with many citing the reported declining rate of new coronavirus helping the oil benchmarks push to the higher end of their February trading ranges; note a bearish EIA weekly report saw prices pare back somewhat. Oil prices were already on the front foot from the Asia session, ignoring a bearish private inventory report on Tuesday evening, before breaking higher as US participants came to their desks. Citigroup's energy analysts highlight the "surge in RBOB gasoline on the back of some unplanned refinery outages, including a fire at Exxon Mobile’s 502k BPD Baton Rouge refinery, although production units don’t appear to have been involved." However, some added greenback strength and an acutely bearish EIA weekly report saw some profit-taking/concession: crude stocks (bbls) built a crushing 7.5mln, more than double expectations and the preliminary indications, while production rose by 100k BPD to 13.0mln BPD; however, the products both printed draws amid a ramp-up in refinery utilisation. Meanwhile, following the Russian Energy Ministry's meeting with domestic corporates to discuss the OPEC+ meeting/extended cut proposals, it was reported that no decision had yet been made, with Lukoil suggesting many were in favour for an extended cut to the end of Q2 but gave no mention of whether the group would support any deeper cuts as the OPEC JTC had recommended. Looking ahead, oil prices now stand at a key point, if global sentiment continues to warm amid failing coronavirus concerns, WTI and Brent could find themselves breaking their February highs of 52.20 and 56.77, respectively, and begin to pare back some of the heavy losses experienced in January - although a worsening global demand picture due to nCoV, in addition to an unsupportive OPEC, could limit further gains.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 10 TICKS LOWER AT 130-22: The TPLEX bear steepened on Wednesday, ahead of Treasury supply with the T-Note seeing the most pronounced selling (compared to other maturities), as risk appetite continued to improve. Similar to Tuesday, the majority of the move happened in the overnight session, before finding its floor in early European trade. Desks note the selling was lead by real money as dealers sought concession ahead of the 10-year auction, in what was, more broadly, the most expensive since October. Nonetheless, the USD 27bln refunding auction was fairly decent, stopping through the 1.623% WI by 0.1bps, covered 2.58x (vs. six-auction average 2.41x), and dealers didn’t have to take down as much as usual, with both directs and indirects taking more than average. How much higher the 10-year yield can move in the near term remains up to debate, there are suggestions of algos/programme sellers “lurking” above 1.64% on the 10-year yield, a level which heavy gamma hedging took place last week, a level which could be tested if expectations move closer to that of a v-shaped recovery in the global economy post the coronavirus. By settlement, yields were higher across the curve with the 10-year yield at 1.63%, seeing the 2s10s widen by just under 1.5bps.

* RBNZ: The OCR was left on hold at 1.00% as was widely expected while issuing a neutral outlook for its key interest rate. The Central Bank noted that policy has time to adjust if needed and that low-interest rates remain necessary to keep employment and inflation around the target. Furthermore, the rate path was lifted in which it sees the OCR at 1.00% in June 2020 and 1.10% in June 2021 (vs. Prev. 0.9% through to March 2021) – thus alluding to no rate cuts during the period, the rate path also imply a hike by end-2021, which some desks perceived as “hawkish” in essence. The Bank warned that the Coronavirus outbreak has presented downside risk, although some were surprised that the RBNZ only assume a 0.3ppt hit to NZD Q1 GDP - “We assume the overall economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in New Zealand will be of a short duration, with most of the impacts in the first half of 2020.”, the statement said. Post-decision, Governor Orr stated that the virus outbreak is a risk that could have a larger impact but reassured the Central Bank has time to respond. Orr added that they are looking at the assumption of a 6-week disruption due to coronavirus and have taken half of the expected GDP growth for Q1 off the table in projections amid the outbreak. In light of the decision, ASB pulled their forecast for a May 2020 OCR reduction “unless the impacts of the coronavirus prove to be much larger and more prolonged than the short, sharp impact viral outbreaks tend to have”

* RIKSBANK: As expected the Riksbank left rates unchanged at 0.0%. Focus going into the meeting was on its outlook for CPIF, on which the Riksbank downgraded its 2020 forecast to 1.3% vs. December’s forecast of 1.7%; citing that falling energy prices are expected to dampen inflation this year. However, their assessment thereafter is that inflation will be in proximity to the 2% target. Prices aside, the repo rate forecast was unchanged from December’s meeting which sees rate unchanged until 2022 where 10bp of upside is priced in. On the macro-front, the Riksbank believes the coronavirus will reduce short-term global growth but, at present, it is difficult to assess the economic consequences fully. Some desks have interpreted this language as a larger acknowledgement of the potential impact of the virus when compared with G10 peers. The subsequent press conference didn’t reveal anything too pertinent aside from reiterations of the initial statement; Governor Ingves stated that as declines in inflation are largely down to inflation, it is hard to see a rate cut. Looking ahead, focus turns to the minutes (21st Feb) any further guidance/commentary on the inflation outlook. More pertinently, given that Breman and Jansson dissented the December rate hike, it will be interesting to acquire their opinion on the decision as from February’s release it does not appear as if there was any significant opposition to this decision.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.64% at 3379, DJIA +0.9% at 29,551, NDX +1% at 9613. SECTORS: Cons Disc +0.99%, Cons Stpl -0.04%, Energy +1.36 %, Financials +0.07%, Health +0.14%, Industrials +0.92%, Materials +0.52%, Real Estate +0.67%, Technology +1.06%, Communication Svs +1.25%, Utilities +0.02%.

* EARNINGS: Molson Coors (TAP) initially opened +3.5% after its earnings report which beat top and bottom-line estimates, however throughout the session gains quickly reversed and closed ~4% lower. Lyft (LYFT) beat on top and bottom-line estimates however the stock ended the day almost 10% lower as analysts highlight it signalled no sign of turning a profit this year, unlike competitor Uber (UBER). Western Union (WU) was hit after its earnings report missed both EPS and revenue expectations.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Micron (MU) traded with solid gains following an upgrade at UBS, where the desk noted the time has finally arrived when MU can materially outperform over a sustained period, believing it is in a much stronger position in a better-positioned industry on the cusp of a cyclical upswing, and that DRAM should perform well in 2021. Elsewhere in the Semiconductor space, Qualcomm (QCOM) opened higher following an upgrade at Daiwa, who noted the potential QCOM has due to its 5G positioning. The energy sector drove gains in the SPX as oil prices rebounded today following the recent heavy declines. Marathon Petroleum (MPC) traded higher boosted by firmer oil prices but also gained on reports TDR capital is interested in its Speedway unit. Defensives (XLP, XLU, XLV) were the relative underperformers on Wednesday, XLP the only sector in the red as gains in TAP reversed course after opening with solid gains. Wynn (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) were higher following an upgrade at UBS. Carnival (CCL) announced it is currently unable to determine the full financial impact of the coronavirus, but noted if it had to suspend Asia operations until the end of April, it would hit FY20 financial performance by USD 0.55-0.65/shr. BedBath & Beyond (BBBY) were slammed after releasing preliminary Q4 SSS, which declined 5.4% due to declines in store traffic combined with inventory management issues, more promotional activity and markdowns.

* FX WRAP: EUR continued to weaken amid a number of factors such as continued weakness in EU data which is leading to growth concerns, while German political woes also failed to provide any favour to the single currency. Desks have also highlighted the conditions for a carry trade continue to show as participants eye higher-yielding currencies, seemingly evident in EURCAD price action which continues to fall. Technical factors were also in play today with EURUSD seemingly held up by 1.6bln worth of option expiries between 1.0900/10. However, after the NY cut weakness continued and the cross breached 1.09 to the downside, and printed a multi-year low at 1.0877, with technicians eyeing 1.0864 as the next Fib support level. USD was firmer primarily driven by EUR weakness as data remained thin and Powell had nothing new to say. The DXY tested 99.00 to the upside before breaking above the key level in late trade, Scotia note that while risk appetite improves, it believes an overbought USD is prone to some corrective pressures. CAD firmer aided by the rebound in oil prices, and also likely as part of the EUR carry trade, USDCAD crossed 1.3250 to the downsie although currently resides at the figure heading into the final hour of trade. USDJPY crossed over 110 this morning after risk appetite improved at the European open, a level it resides around heading into Asia trade amid broad dollar strength. UBS highlight that “as correlations with core global risk assets and indicators of cyclical risk are alive and well”, JPY appears to be an ideal portfolio hedge due to long-term appreciation expectations and its inverse sensitivity risk. XAU saw relatively rangebound trade today with the precious metal trading in an 8 buck range but ending the session rather flat, if not slightly lower on greenback strength. NZD was the G10 outperformer following the RBNZ’s rate decision which signalled no further easing as it increased its forecast for its OCR to 1.1% from 0.9% in June 2021. AUD firmer in sympathy with its Antipodean counterpart. EMFX was mixed with continued weakness seen in TRY amid ongoing Syria conflict while higher oil prices doing little to help the Lira, which conversely supported RUB.

subject: FX Wrap: DXY brakes 99.00 at wrath of Euro weakness
analysis_details: • EUR continued to weaken amid a number of factors such as continued weakness in EU data which is leading to growth concerns, while German political woes also failed to provide any favour to the single currency. Desks have also highlighted the conditions for a carry trade continue to show as participants eye higher-yielding currencies, seemingly evident in EURCAD price action which continues to fall. Technical factors were also in play today with EURUSD seemingly held up by 1.6bln worth of option expiries between 1.0900/10. However, after the NY cut weakness continued and the cross breached 1.09 to the downside, and printed a multi-year low at 1.0877, with technicians eyeing 1.0864 as the next Fib support level. USD was firmer primarily driven by EUR weakness as data remained thin and Powell had nothing new to say. The DXY tested 99.00 to the upside before breaking above the key level in late trade. Scotia note that while risk appetite improves, it believes an overbought USD is prone to some corrective pressures. CAD firmer aided by the rebound in oil prices, and also likely as part of the EUR carry trade, USDCAD crossed 1.3250 to the downsie although currently resides at the figure heading into the final hour of trade. USDJPY crossed over 110 this morning after risk appetite improved at the European open, a level it resides around heading into Asia trade amid broad dollar strength. UBS highlight that “as correlations with core global risk assets and indicators of cyclical risk are alive and well”, JPY appears to be an ideal portfolio hedge due to long-term appreciation expectations and its inverse sensitivity risk. XAU saw relatively rangebound trade today with the precious metal trading in an 8 buck range but ending the session rather flat, if not slightly lower on greenback strength. NZD was the G10 outperformer following the RBNZ’s rate decision which signalled no further easing as it increased its forecast for its OCR to 1.1% from 0.9% in June 2021. AUD firmer in sympathy with its Antipodean counterpart. EMFX was mixed with continued weakness seen in TRY amid ongoing Syria conflict while higher oil prices doing little to help the Lira, which conversely supported RUB.

subject: US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 10 TICKS LOWER AT 130-22
analysis_details: • The TPLEX bear steepened on Wednesday, ahead of Treasury supply with the T-Note seeing the most pronounced selling (compared to other maturities), as risk appetite continued to improve. Similar to Tuesday, the majority of the move happened in the overnight session, before finding its floor in early European trade. Desks note the selling was lead by real money as dealers sought concession ahead of the 10-year auction, in what was, more broadly, the most expensive since October. Nonetheless, the USD 27bln refunding auction was fairly decent, stopping through the 1.623% WI by 0.1bps, covered 2.58x (vs. six-auction average 2.41x), and dealers didn’t have to take down as much as usual, with both directs and indirects taking more than average. How much higher the 10-year yield can move in the near term remains up to debate, there are suggestions of algos/programme sellers “lurking” above 1.64% on the 10-year yield, a level which heavy gamma hedging took place last week, a level which could be tested if expectations move closer to that of a v-shaped recovery in the global economy post the coronavirus. By settlement, yields were higher across the curve with the 10-year yield at 1.63%, seeing the 2s10s widen by just under 1.5bps.

WTI (H0) settles USD 1.23 higher at USD 51.17/bbl; Brent (H0) settles USD 1.78 higher at USD 55.79/bbl
analysis_details: Energy outperformed on Wednesday alongside equities, with many citing the reported declining rate of new coronavirus helping the oil benchmarks push to the higher end of their February trading ranges; note a bearish EIA weekly report saw prices pare back somewhat. Oil prices were already on the front foot from the Asia session, ignoring a bearish private inventory report on Tuesday evening, before breaking higher as US participants came to their desks. Citigroup's energy analysts highlight the "surge in RBOB gasoline on the back of some unplanned refinery outages, including a fire at Exxon Mobile’s 502k BPD Baton Rouge refinery, although production units don’t appear to have been involved." However, some added greenback strength and an acutely bearish EIA weekly report saw some profit-taking/concession: crude stocks (bbls) built a crushing 7.5mln, more than double expectations and the preliminary indications, while production rose by 100k BPD to 13.0mln BPD; however, the products both printed draws amid a ramp-up in refinery utilisation. Meanwhile, following the Russian Energy Ministry's meeting with domestic corporates to discuss the OPEC+ meeting/extended cut proposals, it was reported that no decision had yet been made, with Lukoil suggesting many were in favour for an extended cut to the end of Q2 but gave no mention of whether the group would support any deeper cuts as the OPEC JTC had recommended. Looking ahead, oil prices now stand at a key point, if global sentiment continues to warm amid failing coronavirus concerns, WTI and Brent could find themselves breaking their February highs of 52.20 and 56.77, respectively, and begin to pare back some of the heavy losses experienced in January - although a worsening global demand picture due to nCoV, in addition to an unsupportive OPEC, could limit further gains

subject: US to sell USD 32bln of 10-year Notes at 13:00 EST / 18:00 GMT
content:
• Heading into the auction, SocGen notes that the 10-year sector looks cheap for the upcoming auction from a relative-value perspective, as well as in both asset swap spread and on the curve versus the 5s and 30s wings. Notwithstanding, on the 2s10s curve, which has flattened on aggregate since the start of this year, the 10y sector appears to be expensive on a relative basis; the bank adds, the when-issued yield of the 10-year sector is at its lowest since August 2016, indicating the expensiveness of the sector. Considering the above-mentioned factors, SocGen says it seems apparent that the 10-year auction may not see good demand, however, we should be mindful that safe haven bids can potentially eclipse valuations. Given that the short-end is pegged to Fed expectations, for now, flight to quality could boost demand for the belly of the curve, the bank concludes.

In terms of historical figures:

  • High yield: (prev. 1.869%, six-auction avg. 1.753%)
  • Tail: (prev. 1.6bps, six-auction avg. 0.4bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.45x, six-auction avg. 2.41x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 28.7%, six-auction avg. 26.7%)
  • Direct: (prev. 16.1%, six-auction avg. 14.5%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 55.2%, six-auction avg. 58.8%)

Bids are submitted by 18:00GMT with results submitted shortly afterwards

Daily FX Wrap: Kiwi rules and Norwegian Crown exalted, but king Dollar not dethroned
content:
USD

The Dollar appears to have found a foothold and firm base to resume its upward trajectory after what seemed like a technically bearish formation and turning point on Tuesday. However, the DXY’s relatively swift recharge owes much to the inability of rival currencies to take advantage or extend gains beyond key chart/psychological levels, and it remains to be seen whether the index can clear 99.000 after stalling a whisker ahead of the round number yesterday (98.702-931 range so far vs 98.965 high on Tuesday). For the record, nothing new from Fed chair Powell or Daly and Harker in the run up to the 2nd semi-annual testimony for that matter, but there is still Kaplan to come.

NZD/NOK/AUD/CNH/SEK

Off best levels, but supportive RBNZ policy tailwinds are still keeping the Kiwi on course to top the major league, as Nzd/Usd consolidates above 0.6450 and Aud/Nzd hovers near the bottom of a circa 1.0400-90 band. In short, the OCR was held as widely if not quite unanimously anticipated, but guidance shifted to neutral from a more two-way stance via the statement and rate forecasts that now envisage a 10 bp hike by the middle of 2021 vs a 10 bp ease through Q1 next year previously. Meanwhile, Aud/Usd has tracked moves amidst broadly risk-on trade, but lagged like Usd/Cnh ahead of resistance around 0.6750 and 6.9500 respectively even though China’s health scare shows more signs of reaching a peak. Elsewhere, another rebound in oil has fuelled further Eur/Nok retracement and a dip through 10.0400, while Eur/Sek has finally crossed 10.5000, but more on Euro weakness rather than the Riksbank that essentially rolled out the same repo path that was laid in December and stuck to the rationale for maintaining ZIRP after the +25 bp normalisation.

CAD/GBP

The next best G10s, as the Loonie also benefited from crude’s latest price comeback to test 1.3250 vs its US peer and Sterling maintained post-UK data momentum to get close to 1.3000 and technical resistance in the form of Cable’s 200 DMA, while breaching 0.8400 against the underperforming Eur.

CHF/EUR/JPY

In contrast to the Pound, mixed fortunes for the Franc again, as Usd/Chf sits closer to the upper end of 0.9771-41 parameters, but Eur/Chf just off multi-year lows within 1.0635-62 extremes on the broader common currency weakness noted above that pulled Eur/Usd under Tuesday’s sub-1.0900 trough and close to the 2019 nadir (1.0879 ahead of a key Fib at 1.0864). Similarly, the Yen struggled to hold above 110.00, but pared losses before major support seen at 110.23.

EM 

A rebuke from Russia over action in Syria before some conciliation via a desire to see both sides achieve aims without conflict piled more pressure on the Turkish Lira that breached 6.0500 vs the Dollar in response. However, the Hungarian Forint fared even worse at fresh record lows against the Euro after little impetus from NBH minutes underlining ongoing accommodation and awaiting CPI data tomorrow.

subject: US equities opened at ATH’s; outperformance seen in Micron (MU) following an upgrade at UBS
content:
Winners

  • Micron (MU) +6% following an upgrade at UBS,
  • Molson Coors (TAP) +3.5% after its earnings report which beat top and bottom line estimates
  • Marathon (MPC) +3.5% after its Speedway unit received interest from TDR capital, whilst it also benefits from firmer energy prices

Losers

  • Western Union (WU) -7% after its EPS and revenue missed analyst expectations
  • Abiomed (ABMD) -2.8% following a downgrade to Underweight at Morgan Stanley
  • Bed Bath and Beyond (BBBY) -25% after it reported preliminary Q4 SSS decline of 5.4%.
analysis_details: US indices opened at record highs with outperformance in Micron (MU) after an upgrade at UBS, where the desk noted the time has finally arrived when MU can materially outperform over a sustained period, believing it is in a much stronger position in a better-positioned industry on the cusp of a cyclical upswing, and that DRAM should perform well in 2021. Elsewhere in the Semiconductor space, Qualcomm (QCOM) opened higher following an upgrade at Daiwa, who noted the potential QCOM has due to its 5G positioning. The energy sector drove gains in the SPX at the open as oil prices rebound this morning following the recent heavy declines. Financials also opened higher as yields are higher across the curve. The broader sectors saw defensives underperform with Real Estate, Utilities and Consumer Staples the only sectors in negative territory. Healthcare, however, opened higher as Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) gained after it announced it is working on a coronavirus vaccine with the US HSS. Gains in CVS Health (CVS) also helped the sector after its earnings report.

subject: Russian Defence Ministry says that Turkey has failed to separate moderate opposition militants from terrorists in the Idlib area "we are convinced that Russia and Turkey can successfully complete their Syrian mission by avoiding hasty decisions"
analysis_details:
• Tensions between Turkey and Syria (and indirectly Russia) have moved up a gear in recent days following the collapse of the fragile ceasefire, which was brokered by Turkey and Russia. For reference, Russia heavily backs the Syrian government whilst Turkey supports Syrian rebels. Over the weekend, Turkey reallocated military to Syria whilst yesterday, Syrian government forces conducted shelling which killed five Turkish soldiers. 
  •  As part of its retaliation, Turkish-backed rebels shot down a Syrian helicopter with reports of ongoing to and fro offensives throughout the day. Turkish President Erdogan took an aggressive stance and noted that the Syrian government will “pay a very heavy price” for attacking Turkish troops

OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report (Feb): 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down, global oil supply decreased, OPEC production fell
content:
MAIN POINTS

  • 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 230k BPD from prior report to 990k BPD – the outbreak of the Coronavirus in China during H1 is the major factor behind the downward revision.
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in January decreased by 10k BPD to an average of 100.12mln BPD, up 780k BPD YY.
  • In January, OPEC crude production fell by 509k BPD MM to average 28.86mln BPD, according to secondary sources. Crude output increased in Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, whilst production decreased mainly in Libya (-344k BPD MM), Iraq and Kuwait.

OPEC

  • Demand for OPEC crude in 2020 was revised down by 200k BPD compared to the prior report and stands at 29.3mln BPD, around 1.3mln BPD lower than the 2019 level
  • “The main reason behind the oil demand growth revision and hence the demand for OPEC crude, is the outbreak of the Coronavirus and its expected impact on China’s oil demand and, by extension, global oil demand.”
  • 2019 demand for OPEC crude remained at 30.6mln BPD, unchanged from prior report
  • The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production decreased by 0.5 pp to 28.8% in January compared with the previous month

NON-OPEC

  • 2019 Russian oil production is estimated to have increased by 90k BPD to average 11.44mln BPD
  • For 2020, the FSU oil supply forecast remained unchanged and is expected to grow by 60k BPD YY to average 14.42mln BPD, including downward adjustments in Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan crude oil production in 1Q20 to meet levels agreed upon in the Declaration of Cooperation

US

  • US crude oil production in 2020 is forecast to grow by 880k BPD YY to average 13.12mln BPD
  • Preliminary data indicates that US crude oil imports edged down 1% MM in January to average 6.58mln BPD YY
  • US crude exports averaged 3.4mln BPD in January, according to preliminary data, down from the record high of 3.6mln BPD achieved in the final month of 2019

OECD

  • OECD oil demand was revised down by 80k BPD, mainly due to lower economic projections for OECD Asia Pacific compared with last month, and a warmer-than-expected winter in the Northern Hemisphere, denting heating fuel requirements. The possible effect of Coronavirus on neighbouring countries in OECD Asia Pacific is also accounted for.
  • OECD total product inventories rose by 22.2mln barrels MM in December to stand at 1.455bln barrels. This was 9.0mln barrels above the same time a year ago, but 8.8mln barrels lower than the latest five-year average.

CORONAVIRUS

  • Oil demand growth in China in 2020 is forecast to slow down, y-o-y, reflecting lower economic activities. The recent outbreak of the coronavirus in China necessitated a further downward revision to the country’s oil demand growth forecast compared to last month
  • Chinese oil demand is now revised down by 200k BPD in 1H20 from the previous monthly assessment, resulting in an overall downward revision of 400k BPD in global oil demand growth in 1H20 and hence a downward revision of 200k BPD for the whole year. This is in line with a downward revision to China’s economic growth for 2020 by 0.5 pp to now stand at 5.4%.

WORLD ECONOMY

  • Global economic growth estimate for 2019 to be 2.9%, compared to 3.0% in the previous month.
  • The 2020 GDP growth forecast was revised down to 3.0%, compared to 3.1% in the previous month.
analysis_details:
• Unsurprisingly, the 2020 demand forecast downgrade amid the coronavirus outbreak, is in-fitting with the EIA’s assessment in which it cut its respective forecast by 310k BPD.
  • Both reports also expect US 2020 production to rise (OPEC MOMR 13.12mln BPD; EIA STEO 13.2mln BPD) – current US record production stands at 13.0mln BPD
  • The OPEC report also notes that OPEC oil lost market share yet again, whilst the EIA STEO highlighted that US crude production is poised to rise further this year.
  • Note: OPEC has not yet initiated a 2021 outlook whereas the EIA sees 2021 world oil demand growth forecast at 1.52mln BPD, +140k from the prior report

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer on little direction-changing newsflow for risk sentiment thus far
  • New Hampshire Democratic Primary results projected Bernie Sanders to win as expected with 26.0%, Buttigieg 24.4%, Klobuchar 19.8%, Warren 9.3% and Biden 8.4%
  • RBNZ left rates unchanged at 1.0% and lifted their rate path, as such the NZD significantly outperforms
  • Riksbank left rates unchanged at 0.0% and cut 2020 CPIF projections; albeit, Governor Ingves does not see a cut as likely from this
  • Looking ahead, highlights include OPEC Monthly Oil Report (12:05GMT/07:05EST), Fed’s Powell, Harker & Daly, supply from US
  • Earnings: Cisco Systems, NVIDIA, CME Group

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China reported an additional 2015 coronavirus cases and 97 deaths as of February 11th vs. Prev. 2478 additional cases and 108 deaths on Feb. 10th, to bring total confirmed cases to 44653 and death toll at 1113. (Newswires)

China's Communist Party Standing Committee is to implement prudent monetary policy; including differentiated virus-curbing measures. Are to enhance the strength of macro-policy adjustments, according to State TV. (Newswires)

Japan confirmed another 39 from the cruise ship off Yokohama tested positive for coronavirus including 1 quarantine officer. (Jiji)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains initially limited as coronavirus fears lingered and following the lack of conviction on Wall St. where US stocks notched fresh record highs at the open before gradually fading the moves throughout the day. ASX 200 (+0.5%) traded positively with the biggest movers driven by earnings releases including the largest of the Big 4 banks CBA, resulting in outperformance in the top-weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was also lifted as it played catch up on return from holiday and with SoftBank sitting on double-digit percentage gains following the federal court approval of the merger between its unit Sprint with T-Mobile. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were kept afloat but with the mainland initially indecisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for a neutral daily position and as participants contemplated over the ongoing outbreak in which the number of cases and death toll continued to mount albeit at a slower pace with the additional number of cases at 2015 which is the lowest since January 30th. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the gains in Japanese stocks and following the mixed results at the 10yr inflation-indexed auction, while pressure was also seen in New Zealand bonds in the aftermath of the less dovish statement from the RBNZ.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9718 vs. Exp. 6.9719 (Prev. 6.9897)

US President Trump National Security Adviser O'Brien said coronavirus could have an impact on the phase one deal in which it could affect the size of Chinese purchases of US agriculture goods. (Newswires)

US

New Hampshire Democratic Primary results projected Bernie Sanders to win as expected with 26.0%, Buttigieg 24.4%, Klobuchar 19.8%, Warren 9.3% and Biden 8.4% after 93% of votes were accounted for, while Andrew Yang dropped out of the Democrat Presidential candidate race. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's Cabinet reshuffle tomorrow will not be "a revolution", according to sources, with ministers prepared for a limited shake-up that will see several Remainers promoted at the expense of Leavers. (Telegraph)

EU Industrial Production MM (Dec) -2.1% vs. Exp. -1.6% (Prev. 0.2%); YY (Dec) -4.1% vs. Exp. -2.3% (Prev. -1.5%, Rev. -1.7%)

GEOPOLITICS

US Army is planning to set up a new military command post to cooperate with European allies in countering potential threats from Russia. (WSJ)

US is prepared to sign a deal with the Taliban that would see the withdrawal of US troops and the start of peace talks between the insurgents and the Afghan government, although a deal would only proceed if the Taliban adhere to a pledge to reduce violence over a 7-day period. (NBC)

Turkish President Erdogan will do whatever is necessary; includes air and ground means - Erdogan accuses Russian forces of a massacre in Idlib - Erdogan and Russian President Putin discussed the situation via a phone call. Erdogan adds that Turkey will hopefully see inflation below 8.5% year-end target, trend of falling interest rates will continue. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are mostly higher [Eurostoxx 50 +0.6%] following on from a similar APAC session, which saw Japanese markets return from yesterday’s holiday and close with firm gains. Bourses are largely in the green with the exception of the SMI (-0.2%), led lower by heavyweights Roche (-0.7%), Nestle (-0.6%) and Novartis (-0.3%) - which together account for ~55% of SMI – as sectors reflect risk appetite (healthcare, consumer staples lag and utilities lag). In terms of individual movers – dismal earnings see ABN AMRO (-7.0%) at the foot of the pan-European index after net income and dividend printed sub-par, with interest income falling and impairments rising. On the flip side, Heineken (+6.2%) stands as a top Stoxx 600 gainer following their earnings in which net profit and consolidated beer volume topped estimates, leading to the best performance in over a decade. Kering (+2.2%) shares also benefit from their numbers after metrics beat estimates across the board including the much-watched Gucci Q4 comparable sales growth. Kering also noted that the uncertainties in China do not call into question the Co’s fundamentals in the luxury industry. Thus, European luxury stocks receive tailwinds: Swatch (+1.5%), Richemont (+1%) and LVMH (+0.6%) all trade higher in tandem.

FX

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi is flying and leaving G10 rivals far behind on the back of another shift from the RBNZ towards ending its easing cycle. Nzd/Usd has rebounded sharply following February’s policy guidance tweaks and updated OCR projections that signal no change for the foreseeable future compared to 10 bp easing previously. In fact, the rate path is now pointing to a 1.10% benchmark price by mid-2021 vs 0.9% out to March next year last time, and the only caveat appears to be severe economic contagion from China’s virus. Nzd/Usd is now eyeing resistance ahead of 0.6500 from sub-0.6400 lows and the Aud/Nzd cross has snapped back towards 1.0400 following transitory forays just above 1.0500 of late. However, the Aussie is also outpacing its US peer that is largely consolidating after failing to extend its winning run when the DXY hit a brick wall inches before 99.000, as Aud/Usd probes firmer ground on the 0.6700 handle with some independent impetus from improved Westpac consumer confidence overnight.

GBP/CHF/CAD/EUR - All benefiting from the aforementioned flagging Greenback, albeit to varying degrees, with Cable also capitalising on Tuesday’s UK GDP data rather than any dovish BoE nuances and extending recovery gains beyond 1.2980 towards 1.3000 and the 10 DMA that falls just shy of the big figure (1.2997). Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp is hovering a few pips above 0.8400 as the single currency remains leggy around 1.0900 against the Buck after yet another Eurozone data miss via pan IP and Eur/Usd runs into headwinds at 1.0925. Note also, heavy option expiry interest between the round number and 1.0910 in 1.6 bn may be capping the headline pair ahead of the NY cut. Elsewhere, the Franc is still straddling 0.9750, but trending bullishly vs the Euro around a 1.0650 axis that prefaces multi-year peaks or troughs for the cross, while the Loonie is gleaning more underlying support from oil’s revival to hold above 1.3300 against its NA neighbour.

SCANDI - In contrast to the RBNZ, nothing new at all emanated from the Riksbank’s latest policy meeting as the repo trajectory matched December’s (flat) profile and accompanying statement underlined the likelihood that zero percent will prevail until the end of the forecast horizon. Nevertheless, Eur/Sek has drifted down towards 10.5000 as none of the regular Board dissenters entered reservations and Governor Ingves reiterated the on hold message in the ensuing press conference. However, Eur/Nok has fallen further on the crude price rebound noted above to test bids/support in front of 10.0500.

EM - Ongoing recovery gains across the region and the Rand only partially hampered by another SA data miss (retail sales), but no respite for the Lira as Turkish President Erdogan ramps up his verbal threats to repel attacks by Syrian Government sources to prevent the Try maintaining an attempt to regain 6.0000+ status.

RBNZ kept the Official Cash Rate unchanged as expected at 1.00%. RBNZ noted that policy has time to adjust if needed, that low interest rates remain necessary and inflation is close to the mid-point. Furthermore, the RBNZ added that employment was at or slightly above maximum sustainable level and sees the overall impact from coronavirus will be of a short duration. Furthermore, the RBNZ adjusted forecasts of the rate path in which it sees OCR at 1.00% in June 2020 1.10% in June 2021 vs. Prev. forecasts of 0.9% through to March 2021. (Newswires) RBNZ Governor Orr said there are many signs household spending growth is increasing and noted that coronavirus is a risk which could have a larger impact although the central bank has time to respond, while it added they are looking at the assumption of 6-week disruption due to coronavirus and have taken half of the expected GDP growth for Q1 off the table in projections amid the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

Riksbank kept rates unchanged at 0.0% as expected, additionally they did not make any changes to their repo path which sees rates on hold until 2022 where the path sees rates at 0.1%. The Riksbank did acknowledge that falling energy prices are expected to dampen inflation this year, after which, they will return to near target. As such, 2020 CPIF target was cut to 1.3% vs. December’s forecast of 1.7%. Subsequently, Governor Ingves stated it is hard to see a rate cut as falling inflation is predominantly on low energy prices.

Major FX option expiries for today's NY cut

-        EUR/USD: 1.0900-10 (1.6BLN), 1.0920 (327M), 1.0955-60 (700M), 1.0980 (250M)

-        USD/CHF: 0.9700 (1.1BLN)

-        AUD/USD: 0.6700 (2.1BLN), 0.6750 (820M)

-        GBP/USD: 1.2890 (281M), 1.2925 (386M), 1.2975 (209M), 1.3000 (820M), 1.3020 (200M)

-        NZD/USD: 0.6450 (500M)

-        USD/JPY: 109.00 (1BLN), 110.00-05 (1.2BLN)

FIXED INCOME

A spirited if not quite compelling or complete comeback from worst levels by Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries as the 10 year debt futures recently rebounded to/towards 147.17, 131.14 and 130-30 vs 173.72, 133.82 and 130-20+ respectively amidst a modest fade/stall in EU stocks as a proxy for risk sentiment in general. The German benchmark may have forged some support via a solid 2030 offering, all things considered, but nowhere near as much as BTPs following bumper demand for Italy’s 2036 syndication with orders almost reaching Spanish record levels. Ahead, more issuance via the Usd32 bn 10 year sale, earnings and the 2nd instalment from Fed chair Powell after colleagues Harker and Daly.

COMMODITIES – OPEC Report will be released at 12:05GMT/07:05EST

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue their upward trajectories with the contracts piggy-backing the broad risk appetite across the market, amid the slowing rate of COVID-19 cases/deaths coupled with reports of positive therapies and resumptions in Chinese operations. WTI Mar’20 futures reside north of USD 50.50/bbl with prices eyeing USD 51.00/bbl ahead of potential resistance at the USD 51.50/bbl mark, which coincides with the 7th Feb high. Brent Apr’20 futures came across mild resistance in early EU trade at USD 55.38/bbl (7th Feb high) ahead of further potential resistance around USD 55.55/bbl (6th Feb high). On the OPEC front, a definite OPEC+ meeting date remains in question, with desks noting that the longer we wait, the more likely that the meeting will take place in March as opposed to late-February. Russian Energy Minister Novak will today be meeting with domestic oil companies to discuss Moscow’s stance on deeper/prolonged output reductions. Elsewhere, yesterday’s APIs, which showed a larger-than-forecast build (+6mln vs. Exp. +3mln), did little to provide sustained pressure in prices as sentiment underpins the benchmarks – participants will be on the lookout to see if the weekly DoE numbers align with those of the API. Yesterday also saw the release of the EIA STEO ahead of today’s OPEC monthly oil report. The STEO cut 2020 oil demand growth by 310k BPD, downgraded US crude output forecasts and noted the uncertainty surrounding the virus outbreak, again little sustained reaction. Next up, OPEC’s monthly report will garner interest as this is the report that will encapsulate coronavirus forecasts as well as OPEC output since the December meeting. In terms of metals, spot gold trades lacklustre on either side of the 21 DMA (USD ~1566/oz), in-fitting with the current risk appetite. Copper prices remain supported by the risk tone but within yesterday’s ranges awaiting the next catalyst. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures hit three-week highs as coronavirus cases/deaths slowed and following a 22.4% YY drop in Vale’s Q4 iron ore production.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 7th Jan) +6.0mln (exp. +3.0mln, prev. +4.18mln). (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Sentiment supported, but news-flow light ahead of Powell day 2 - 12th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities are mostly higher [Eurostoxx 50 +0.6%] following on from a similar APAC session, which saw Japanese markets return from yesterday’s holiday and close with firm gains. Bourses are largely in the green with the exception of the SMI (-0.2%), led lower by heavyweights Roche (-0.7%), Nestle (-0.6%) and Novartis (-0.3%) - which together account for ~55% of SMI – as sectors reflect risk appetite (healthcare, consumer staples lag and utilities lag). In terms of individual movers – dismal earnings see ABN AMRO (-7.0%) at the foot of the pan-European index after net income and dividend printed sub-par, with interest income falling and impairments rising. On the flip side, Heineken (+6.2%) stands as a top Stoxx 600 gainer following their earnings in which net profit and consolidated beer volume topped estimates, leading to the best performance in over a decade. Kering (+2.2%) shares also benefit from their numbers after metrics beat estimates across the board including the much-watched Gucci Q4 comparable sales growth. Kering also noted that the uncertainties in China do not call into question the Co’s fundamentals in the luxury industry. Thus, European luxury stocks receive tailwinds: Swatch (+1.5%), Richemont (+1%) and LVMH (+0.6%) all trade higher in tandem.

FX

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi is flying and leaving G10 rivals far behind on the back of another shift from the RBNZ towards ending its easing cycle. Nzd/Usd has rebounded sharply following February’s policy guidance tweaks and updated OCR projections that signal no change for the foreseeable future compared to 10 bp easing previously. In fact, the rate path is now pointing to a 1.10% benchmark price by mid-2021 vs 0.9% out to March next year last time, and the only caveat appears to be severe economic contagion from China’s virus. Nzd/Usd is now eyeing resistance ahead of 0.6500 from sub-0.6400 lows and the Aud/Nzd cross has snapped back towards 1.0400 following transitory forays just above 1.0500 of late. However, the Aussie is also outpacing its US peer that is largely consolidating after failing to extend its winning run when the DXY hit a brick wall inches before 99.000, as Aud/Usd probes firmer ground on the 0.6700 handle with some independent impetus from improved Westpac consumer confidence overnight.

GBP/CHF/CAD/EUR - All benefiting from the aforementioned flagging Greenback, albeit to varying degrees, with Cable also capitalising on Tuesday’s UK GDP data rather than any dovish BoE nuances and extending recovery gains beyond 1.2980 towards 1.3000 and the 10 DMA that falls just shy of the big figure (1.2997). Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp is hovering a few pips above 0.8400 as the single currency remains leggy around 1.0900 against the Buck after yet another Eurozone data miss via pan IP and Eur/Usd runs into headwinds at 1.0925. Note also, heavy option expiry interest between the round number and 1.0910 in 1.6 bn may be capping the headline pair ahead of the NY cut. Elsewhere, the Franc is still straddling 0.9750, but trending bullishly vs the Euro around a 1.0650 axis that prefaces multi-year peaks or troughs for the cross, while the Loonie is gleaning more underlying support from oil’s revival to hold above 1.3300 against its NA neighbour.

SCANDI - In contrast to the RBNZ, nothing new at all emanated from the Riksbank’s latest policy meeting as the repo trajectory matched December’s (flat) profile and accompanying statement underlined the likelihood that zero percent will prevail until the end of the forecast horizon. Nevertheless, Eur/Sek has drifted down towards 10.5000 as none of the regular Board dissenters entered reservations and Governor Ingves reiterated the on hold message in the ensuing press conference. However, Eur/Nok has fallen further on the crude price rebound noted above to test bids/support in front of 10.0500.

EM - Ongoing recovery gains across the region and the Rand only partially hampered by another SA data miss (retail sales), but no respite for the Lira as Turkish President Erdogan ramps up his verbal threats to repel attacks by Syrian Government sources to prevent the Try maintaining an attempt to regain 6.0000+ status.

FIXED INCOME                                                              

A spirited if not quite compelling or complete comeback from worst levels by Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries as the 10 year debt futures recently rebounded to/towards 147.17, 131.14 and 130-30 vs 173.72, 133.82 and 130-20+ respectively amidst a modest fade/stall in EU stocks as a proxy for risk sentiment in general. The German benchmark may have forged some support via a solid 2030 offering, all things considered, but nowhere near as much as BTPs following bumper demand for Italy’s 2036 syndication with orders almost reaching Spanish record levels. Ahead, more issuance via the Usd32 bn 10 year sale, earnings and the 2nd instalment from Fed chair Powell after colleagues Harker and Daly.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue their upward trajectories with the contracts piggy-backing the broad risk appetite across the market, amid the slowing rate of COVID-19 cases/deaths coupled with reports of positive therapies and resumptions in Chinese operations. WTI Mar’20 futures reside north of USD 50.50/bbl with prices eyeing USD 51.00/bbl ahead of potential resistance at the USD 51.50/bbl mark, which coincides with the 7th Feb high. Brent Apr’20 futures came across mild resistance in early EU trade at USD 55.38/bbl (7th Feb high) ahead of further potential resistance around USD 55.55/bbl (6th Feb high). On the OPEC front, a definite OPEC+ meeting date remains in question, with desks noting that the longer we wait, the more likely that the meeting will take place in March as opposed to late-February. Russian Energy Minister Novak will today be meeting with domestic oil companies to discuss Moscow’s stance on deeper/prolonged output reductions. Elsewhere, yesterday’s APIs, which showed a larger-than-forecast build (+6mln vs. Exp. +3mln), did little to provide sustained pressure in prices as sentiment underpins the benchmarks – participants will be on the lookout to see if the weekly DoE numbers align with those of the API. Yesterday also saw the release of the EIA STEO ahead of today’s OPEC monthly oil report. The STEO cut 2020 oil demand growth by 310k BPD, downgraded US crude output forecasts and noted the uncertainty surrounding the virus outbreak, again little sustained reaction. Next up, OPEC’s monthly report will garner interest as this is the report that will encapsulate coronavirus forecasts as well as OPEC output since the December meeting. In terms of metals, spot gold trades lacklustre on either side of the 21 DMA (USD ~1566/oz), in-fitting with the current risk appetite. Copper prices remain supported by the risk tone but within yesterday’s ranges awaiting the next catalyst. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures hit three-week highs as coronavirus cases/deaths slowed and following a 22.4% YY drop in Vale’s Q4 iron ore production.

subject: Shell (RDSA LN) reports a leak at their Deer Park, Texas refinery (275k BPD), Community Alert

China's Communist Party Standing Committee is to implement prudent monetary policy; including differentiated virus-curbing measures. Are to enhance the strength of macro-policy adjustments, according to State TV
Nomura Quants – Participants remain doubtful over a reflation-trade emanating from China
content:
• US Investors appear to have some doubts around whether a liquidity-driven, reflationary market fuelled by policy action in China is occurring. Believing that some of the markets gains have been exaggerated by mass inflows from systematic players who are essentially trend-following, as well as CTAs.
  • Particularly, as fundamental based investors, within the cash market at least, remain somewhat sceptical of the narrative that negative China updates are positive for the market.
  • FX traders appearing to be taking a similar stance. CTA data indicates that they are purchasing the USD at a large rate, and this looks to be against a wide range of currencies. Additionally, trend-followers are aligning themselves with China-bear trades such as being short Yuan and traditional commodity currencies.
  • Overall, the significant improvement in Chinese sentiment has increased global risk-taking but this is in a somewhat conspicuous way. If markets become more expectations driven, on the idea that bad news is good news, then speculative traders may begun partaking in reflation-driven trades as of late-February.

subject: European Equity Movers this Morning: Heineken (HEIA NA) +2.5%; Kering (KER FP) +2.5%; Ahold Delhaize (AD NA) +0.8%; Akzo Nobel (AKZA NA) +0.8%; ABN AMRO (ABN NA) -5.0%; Amundi (AMUN IM) -2.6%; Sanofi (SAN FP) -0.6%
Bunds: making way for more stock gains and supply
content: The 10 year German benchmark has been veering lower from the outset in recognition of another dial down in anxiety over the Chinese virus and with some additional concession building ahead of issuance as the technical backdrop for bonds turns more bearish. Indeed, Bunds have now breached chart support at 174.01 and briefly dipped below the low from NFP day to nudge the equivalent yield closer to -35 bp ahead of the Eur4 bn 2030 auction and 2nd leg of this week’s US refunding in the form of Usd32 bn 10 year notes. Also ahead, ECB’s Lane is scheduled to orate again before a trio of Fed speakers including chair Powell’s Senate testimony and 2nd semi-annual Q&A session. Back to Eurex, the core debt future is hovering near the base of a 174.17-173.80 range vs Tuesday's 174.26 close.

Co. expects FCF of around EUR 1.5bln for FY20, affected by the cash impact of EUR 270mln in capital expenditures related to US supply chain transformation. Co. remains on track to reach goal of doubling net consumer online sales. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Sri Lankan Government is reportedly evaluating ways to recover damages and claim relevant compensation from the Co. following their bribing of officials to secure orders. For context, Co. recently agrees to a USD 4bln bribery settlement. (Newswires)

Babcock (BAB LN) – Expectations for underlying EPS are in-line with current expectations. Co. is to write down assets and leases in oil and gas business. Co. expects to incur an exceptional restructuring charge of GBP 85mln. Combined book order remains at record levels. Co. is to exit oil and gas business in Ghana and Congo. (Newswires)

Commerzbank (CBK GY) – ECB has urged Co. to speed up restructuring efforts with top financial regulator expressing concerns about lacklustre profitability. Regulatory official urged the Co. to consider deeper cost cuts, according to sources. (FT)

Kering (KER FP) – FY19 net EUR 2.31bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.29bln. Recurring operating profit EUR 4.78bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.73bln. Revenue EUR 15.88bln vs. Exp. EUR 15.8bln. Co. recommends dividend of EUR 11.50/shr, +10% YY. FY gross margin +15.5% to EUR 11.78bln. Gucci Q4 comparable sales growth 10.5% vs. Exp. 8.6%. Co. notes that group’s operating environment remains unsettled with regards to macroeconomics and geopolitical uncertainties, national trade policies, and FX fluctuations. CEO said uncertainties in China do not call into question Co’s fundamentals in the luxury industry. CEO is confident in growth potential in mid and long-term. (Newswires) For reference, Co. has a 0.5% weighting in the Stoxx 600 and a 1.6% weighting in the EuroStoxx 50.

content:

12th February 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher but with gains limited as coronavirus fears lingered and following the lack of conviction on Wall St. where US stocks notched fresh record highs at the open before gradually fading the moves throughout the day. ASX 200 (+0.5%) traded positive with the biggest movers driven by earnings releases including the largest of the Big 4 banks CBA which despite posting a decline in H1 net, still beat expectations resulting to outperformance in the top-weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also lifted as it played catch up on return from holiday and with SoftBank sitting on double-digit percentage gains following the federal court approval of the merger between its unit Sprint with T-Mobile. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were kept afloat but with the mainland initially indecisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for a neutral daily position and as participants contemplated over the ongoing outbreak in which the number of cases and death toll continued to mount albeit at a slower pace with the additional number of cases at 2015 which is the lowest since January 30th.

Softbank (9984 JT) – Q3 net income JPY 55.014bln, operating income JPY 2.59bln. Co. still sees FY dividend at JPY 44 vs. Exp. JPY 44. Vision Fund loss JPY 225.12bln. 9-month net declines 69% Y/Y to JPY 476.6bln, although returns to profit for Q3. (Newswires)

FTSE 100

Energy Names – Ofgem, the energy regulator, has said that gas and electric customers will now receive automatic compensation totalling GBP 30 as of May. In the event that a switch to a new provider takes longer than 15 days or it taking over 6-weeks to receive a final bill. (BBC)

Technology Names – UK Government are reportedly to confirm today that Ofcom is to be provided the power to make such firms responsible for the protection of users from harmful content; unclear as to what penalties they will be able to implement. (BBC)

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains limited as coronavirus fears lingered
  • China reported an additional 2015 coronavirus cases and 97 deaths as of February 11th to bring total confirmed cases to 44653 and death toll at 1113
  • RBNZ stood pat on rates as expected, whilst adopting an overall neutral tone
  • EIA lowered its forecast for world oil demand growth for this year but increased its estimate for 2021 and reduced its forecast for US crude output growth
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Industrial Production, Riksbank rate decision, OPEC Monthly Oil Report, ECB’s Lane, Fed’s Powell, Harker & Daly, Riksbank’s Ingves, supply from Germany & US
  • Earnings: Cisco Systems, NVIDIA, CVS Corp, CME Group, ABN AMRO, Ahold Delhaize, Akzo Nobel

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China reported an additional 2015 coronavirus cases and 97 deaths as of February 11th vs. Prev. 2478 additional cases and 108 deaths on Feb. 10th, to bring total confirmed cases to 44653 and death toll at 1113. (Newswires)

Japan confirmed another 39 from the cruise ship off Yokohama tested positive for coronavirus including 1 quarantine officer. (Jiji)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains limited as coronavirus fears lingered and following the lack of conviction on Wall St. where US stocks notched fresh record highs at the open before gradually fading the moves throughout the day. ASX 200 (+0.5%) traded positively with the biggest movers driven by earnings releases including the largest of the Big 4 banks CBA, resulting in outperformance in the top-weighted financials sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also lifted as it played catch up on return from holiday and with SoftBank sitting on double-digit percentage gains following the federal court approval of the merger between its unit Sprint with T-Mobile. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were kept afloat but with the mainland initially indecisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for a neutral daily position and as participants contemplated over the ongoing outbreak in which the number of cases and death toll continued to mount albeit at a slower pace with the additional number of cases at 2015 which is the lowest since January 30th. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the gains in Japanese stocks and following the mixed results at the 10yr inflation-indexed auction, while pressure was also seen in New Zealand bonds in the aftermath of the less dovish statement from the RBNZ.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9718 vs. Exp. 6.9719 (Prev. 6.9897)

US President Trump National Security Adviser O'Brien said coronavirus could have an impact on the phase one deal in which it could affect the size of Chinese purchases of US agriculture goods. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's Cabinet reshuffle tomorrow will not be "a revolution", according to sources, with ministers prepared for a limited shake-up that will see several Remainers promoted at the expense of Leavers. (Telegraph)

BoE Governor Carney said EU financial services equivalence regime is "relatively unstable" and that London will remain the gateway to global markets for many including Europe, for the foreseeable future. (Newswires)

BoE's Haskel said the current limited room on monetary policy means he continues to prefer to move now on rates and trend towards intangible assets reinforces low rate environment. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said we are currently at a stage in which accommodative policy is still required. (Newswires)

ECB's Schnabel said the ECB's current policy stance is necessary to achieve sustained price stability in the Euro area and that developments in real estate prices are rightly coming under scrutiny. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was steady and consolidated after having recently pulled back from resistance just shy of the 99.00 level, with the greenback finding little to spur price action from Fed Chair Powell who stuck to the script in the first day of his testimony to Congress, while the ongoing New Hampshire Democrat Primary results also failed to provide any major surprises with Sanders projected to win as expected given the home advantage with him being the Senator from the neighbouring state of Vermont. Elsewhere, EUR/USD was stuck within yesterday’s tight range and GBP/USD held above 1.2950, while USD/JPY found mild support from the risk appetite. Antipodeans were the biggest gainers with NZD/USD surging after the RBNZ kept rates unchanged as expected and revised its forecast for the rate path in which it now sees the OCR at 1.1% in June 2021 vs. Prev. forecasts of 0.9% through to March 2021.

RBNZ kept the Official Cash Rate unchanged as expected at 1.00%. RBNZ noted that policy has time to adjust if needed, that low interest rates remain necessary and inflation is close to the mid-point. Furthermore, the RBNZ added that employment was at or slightly above maximum sustainable level and sees the overall impact from coronavirus will be of a short duration. Furthermore, the RBNZ adjusted forecasts of the rate path in which it sees OCR at 1.00% in June 2020 1.10% in June 2021 vs. Prev. forecasts of 0.9% through to March 2021. (Newswires) RBNZ Governor Orr said there are many signs household spending growth is increasing and noted that coronavirus is a risk which could have a larger impact although the central bank has time to respond, while it added they are looking at the assumption of 6-week disruption due to coronavirus and have taken half of the expected GDP growth for Q1 off the table in projections amid the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly higher amid the predominantly positive risk tone during Asia trade which saw WTI crude futures shrug-off the mild pressure from the larger than expected build in headline private sector crude inventories and bounce back above the USD 50.00/bbl level. EIA released its Short-Term Energy Outlook in which it lowered its forecast for world oil demand growth for this year but increased its estimate for next year and reduced its forecast for US crude output growth. Gold prices were kept subdued, while copper gained in tandem with the mostly upbeat sentiment and continued strength in Chinese commodity prices. 

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 7th Jan) +6.0mln (exp. +3.0mln, prev. +4.18mln). (Newswires)

EIA STEO cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 310k BPD to 1.03mln BPD but raised forecast for 2021 world oil demand growth by 140k BPD to 1.52mln BPD. Furthermore, it sees US crude output to rise 960k BPD to 13.2mln BPD in 2020 (prev. rise of 1.06mln BPD) and increase 360k BPD to 13.56mln BPD in 2021 (prev. rise of 410k BPD). EIA added that the magnitude and duration of the coronavirus’s effects remain highly uncertain, although it is reducing estimates for Chinese and global oil consumption. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US Army is planning to set up a new military command post to cooperate with European allies in countering potential threats from Russia. (WSJ)

US is prepared to sign a deal with the Taliban that would see the withdrawal of US troops and the start of peace talks between the insurgents and the Afghan government, although a deal would only proceed if the Taliban adhere to a pledge to reduce violence over a 7-day period. (NBC)

 

US 

The TPLEX pared-back Monday’s gains overnight before finding a floor in the European session. Although US equities opened at new ATHs, participants weren’t eager to push yields any higher, following on from Monday where yields pushed lower despite an equity rally. The curve structure was little changed too, with some desks noting the 3-year auction as keeping the front/belly end weighted: the auction tailed the 1.392% WI by 2bps and Dealers took a larger share than usual, although it was covered 2.56x, higher than the six-auction average. By settlement, yields up to the 10-year maturity were higher by just over 4bps, while the 30-year was only 3bps higher. US T-note futures (H20) settled 11+ ticks lower at 131.00.

Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) stated interest rates are slightly accommodative and are not providing much of a boost, while he suggested that it seems like the battles between the US and China on trade are not getting worse but noted that coronavirus is a downside risk for China and if it hits the US in scale it would also be a downside risk here. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said that China’s economy is expected to slow noticeably this quarter due to the coronavirus, while the best case for the US is a soft landing following the recent rate cuts as housing and other interest rate-sensitive sectors rebound. Bullard also stated it is appropriate to remain steady on rates and that progress is needed to be seen on inflation, while he would welcome inflation readings above 2%. Furthermore, Bullard noted that monetary policy currently feels a "little bit accommodative" and that rate normalisation of previous years will "pay dividends" as the Fed has scope to react to a downturn. (Newswires)

New Hampshire Democratic Primary results projected Bernie Sanders to win as expected with 26.0%, Buttigieg 24.4%, Klobuchar 19.8%, Warren 9.3% and Biden 8.4% after 93% of votes were accounted for, while Andrew Yang dropped out of the Democrat Presidential candidate race. (Newswires)

Senate Majority Leader McConnell said he does not believe the Senate and House could reach an agreement on the budget this year. (Newswires)

In FX markets, the DXY is steady and consolidates after having recently pulled back from resistance just shy of the 99.00 level, with the greenback finding little to spur price action from Fed Chair Powell who stuck to the script in the first day of his testimony to Congress, while the ongoing New Hampshire Democrat Primary results have also failed to provide any major surprises with Bernie Sanders leading as expected given the home advantage with him being the Senator from the neighbouring state of Vermont.
